```{r setup, include=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=TRUE}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(faux)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(gt)
penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins
# the following creates a sample that has 100 observations of 2
# variables, drawn from a population where 
# - X has a mean of 0 and SD of 1 
# - Y has a mean of 20 and SD of 5
# - X correlates with Y with r = 0.75
cor90df <- rnorm_multi(n = 300, 
                  mu = c(0, 20),
                  sd = c(1, 5),
                  r = c(0.90), 
                  varnames = c("X", "Y"),
                  empirical = FALSE)
cor20df <- rnorm_multi(n = 300, 
                  mu = c(0, 20),
                  sd = c(1, 5),
                  r = c(0.20), 
                  varnames = c("X", "Y"),
                  empirical = FALSE)
```

# Why do we need graphs? {.smaller}

## Raw data don't communicate well {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
It's hard to make sense of millions of rows and/or thousands of columns
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
Fortunately, we are **excellent at seeing patterns**:
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #ffac00;"}
"*the human brain has a superior ability to mentally manipulate animate
and inanimate patterns into a myriad of intangible symbols that can then
be recombined to produce new images of the world;* "
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #ffac00;"}
"*we therefore live partly in worlds of our own mental creation,
super-imposed upon or distinct from the natural world.*"
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #05ffa1;"}
\- Source: [Superior pattern processing is the essence of the evolved
human
brain](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2014.00265/full)
:::

# Graphs allow us to explore complexity with ***symbols*** and ***images*** {.smaller}

## Exploratory Data Analysis

<br>

"Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)" first coined by American mathematician
John Tukey in 1977

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r eda-tukey, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.height='35%', out.width='35%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/eda-tukey.jpg")
```
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #ffac00;"}
"*The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we
never expected to see.*"
:::
:::
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.95em; color: #05ffa1;"}
\- John Tukey,
[1977](http://www.ru.ac.bd/wp-content/uploads/sites/25/2019/03/102_05_01_Tukey-Exploratory-Data-Analysis-1977.pdf)
:::

# Exploration requires 'listening'

<br><br>

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 1.50em; color: #ffac00;"}
*"The role of the data analyst is to listen to the data in as many ways
as possible until a plausible 'story' of the data is apparent"*
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.95em; color: #05ffa1;"}
\- John T. Behrens, [Principles and Procedures of Exploratory Data
Analysis](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/1997-06270-001)
:::

# Exploration is a 'state of mind'

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #ffac00;"}
*"More than anything, EDA is a state of mind. During the initial phases
of EDA you should feel free to investigate every idea that occurs to
you. Some of these ideas will pan out, and some will be dead ends..."*
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #ffac00;"}
*"As your exploration continues, you will hone in on a few particularly
productive areas that you'll eventually write up and communicate to
others."*
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.95em; color: #05ffa1;"}
\- Hadley Wickham, [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/eda)
:::

# An Exploratory Mindset

## Exploration requires a Bayesian Mindset (1 of 3) {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.50em;"}
We all have implicit beliefs, or priors, about the world
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #3D9CD8;"}
*What we think we know (i.e.,our expectations)*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
```{r bayesian-eda-prior-png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='65%', out.width='65%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/bayesian-eda-priors.png")
```
:::
:::

## Exploration requires a Bayesian Mindset (2 of 3) {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.50em;"}
When we encounter new information or data, our priors get updated
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #3D9CD8;"}
*Our expectations + new data (i.e., what we see)*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
```{r bayesian-eda-new-png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='59%', out.width='59%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/bayesian-eda-new.png")
```
:::
:::

## Exploration requires a Bayesian Mindset (3 of 3) {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.50em;"}
Our updated beliefs, or posteriors, depend on our priors ***and*** our
perceptions of the new information
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #3D9CD8;"}
*What we expect + what we see = what we've learned*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
```{r bayesian-eda-posteriors.png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='60%', out.width='60%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/bayesian-eda-posteriors.png")
```
:::
:::

## Graphs can confirm our expectations {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: question
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
*What if our expectation was that **X** is related to **Y**?*
:::
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="20%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
<br><br><br> *...then we graphed the data...*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="80%"}
```{r cor90df, fig.align='right', echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data = cor90df, mapping = aes(x = X, y = Y)) + 
  geom_point(size = 3)
```
:::
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 1.40em; color: #3D9CD8;"}
*We would say our expectations have been **confirmed***
:::

## Graphs can refute our expectations {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: question
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
*What if our expectation was that **X** is related to **Y**?*
:::
:::

. . .

::: columns
::: {.column width="20%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
<br><br><br> *...then we graphed the data...*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="80%"}
```{r cor20df, fig.align='right', echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data = cor20df, mapping = aes(x = X, y = Y)) + 
  geom_point(size = 3)
```
:::
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 1.45em; color: #3D9CD8;"}
*We would say our expectations have been **refuted***
:::

# `ggplot2` : grammar & syntax {.smaller}

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em;"}
Built on top of the grammar & syntax of R
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.40em;"}
> "*In R, objects are like nouns, and functions (**fn**) are like
> verbs*"
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r fn-object, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
fn(object)
```
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
:::
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.40em;"}
**functions** do things to *objects*
:::

## `ggplot2`: a layered language for graphs

<br>

. . .

`ggplot2` is comprised of layers  

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.incremental}
- Data 
- Mapping 
- Statistics 
- Geometric objects  
- Position adjustments  
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r ggplot2-layers, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='85%', out.width='85%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/ggplot2-layers.png")
```
:::
:::


## `ggplot2`: data 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
The **data layer** consists of a rectangular object (like a spreadsheet) with columns and rows
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="39%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
```{r data-layer-code, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = penguins)
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}

::::

:::: {.column width="59%"}
::: {.fragment}
```{r data-layer, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='75%', out.width='75%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/data-layer.png")
```
:::
::::
:::::


## `ggplot2`: mapping 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
The **mapping layer** assigns columns (variables) from the data to a visual property (i.e. graph '**`aes`**'thetic)
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="39%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.50em;"}
```{r mapping-layer-code, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = penguins,
  mapping = 
    aes(x = flipper_length_mm, 
      y = bill_length_mm))
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}

::::

:::: {.column width="59%"}
::: {.fragment}
```{r mapping-layer.png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='70%', out.width='70%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/mapping-layer.png")
```
:::
::::
:::::

## `ggplot2`: geoms 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
`geom_*()` functions include statistical transformations, shapes, and position adjustments for how to 'draw' the data on the graph
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="39%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
```{r geom-layer-code, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = penguins,
  mapping = aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_point()
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}

::::

:::: {.column width="59%"}
::: {.fragment}
```{r geom-layer.png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='70%', out.width='70%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/geom-layer.png")
```
:::
::::
:::::

## `ggplot2`: layers 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
We can have multiple layers (data, mappings, geoms) in a single graph
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="39%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
```{r layers-layer-code, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|3|4|5|9|10|11|12"
ggplot(data = penguins,
 # layer 1
  mapping = aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_point()
# layer 2
  geom_smooth(
    mapping = aes(
      x = flipper_length_mm,
      y = bill_length_mm,
      color = species))
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}

::::

:::: {.column width="59%"}
::: {.fragment}
```{r layers-layer.png, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='70%', out.width='70%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/layers-layer.png")
```
:::
::::
:::::

# Layers = infinitely extensible 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
`ggplot2` is a system for,
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.20em;"}
> “*making infinite use of finite means*” - [Wilhelm von Humboldt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_von_Humboldt)
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
***With a finite number of objects & functions, we can combine `ggplot2`'s grammar and syntax to create an infinite number of graphs!***
:::

# `ggplot2`: templates 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
**Basic Template**: [Data,]{.fragment .fade-in} [aesthetic mappings,]{.fragment .fade-in} [geom]{.fragment .fade-in}
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.62em;"}
```{r , eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
  geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>))
```
:::
:::


::: {.column width="2%"}

:::

::: {.column width="49%"}
```{r ggplot2-layers-dark, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='right', out.height='80%', out.width='80%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/ggplot2-layers-dark.png")
```
:::
:::

# `ggplot2`: more templates 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
**Template + 1 Layer**: [more geoms]{.fragment .fade-in} [and more aesthetic mappings]{.fragment .fade-in}
:::

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="58%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.65em;"}
```{r , eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>))
```
:::
:::


::: {.column width="2%"}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
```{r ggplot2-2layers-dark, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='65%', out.width='65%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/ggplot2-2layers-dark.png")
```
:::
:::

# `ggplot2`: even more! 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
**Template + 1 Layer + Facet Layer**: [template,]{.fragment .fade-in} [more aesthetic mappings,]{.fragment .fade-in} [and facets!]{.fragment .fade-in}
:::



. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="58%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.65em;"}
```{r , eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    facet_*
```
:::
:::


::: {.column width="1%"}
:::

::: {.column width="41%"}
```{r ggplot2-3layers-dark, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='50%', out.width='50%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/ggplot2-3layers-dark.png")
```
:::
:::

## Templates = infinitely extensible! 

<br>

. . .


**Themes**

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r , eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    facet_* +
    theme_*
```
:::

. . .

**Don't forget labels!**

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r , eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) +
    facet_* +
    theme_* +
    labs()
```
:::

## `ggplot2`: build the labels first!

. . .

<br>

Create a `title`, `subtitle` (with data source), and `x`/`y` axis labels

. . .

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em"}
```{r labs_pengiuns, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
labs_pengiuns <- ggplot2::labs(
  title = "Flipper vs. Bill Length",
  subtitle = "source: palmerpenguins::penguins",
  x = "flipper length (mm)",
  y = "bill length (mm)")
```
:::
:::

::: {.column width="2%"}

:::

::: {.column width="38%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.95em; color: #ff0202;"}
**<- expectations**
:::
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}

Revision Sharpens Thinking: 
:::
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}

*"More particularly, rewriting is the key to ***improved thinking***. It demands a real open-mindedness and objectivity."*

::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #ffac00;"}

:::

# Global vs. local mapping

## Global mapping 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
The previous graphs mapped aesthetics globally
:::

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}

**Global** = aesthetics are mapped when the graph is initialized with `ggplot()`:

<br>

```{r global-aes-ex, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "3-4"
ggplot(data = penguins,
  mapping = aes(
    x = bill_length_mm,
    y = flipper_length_mm)) 
```
:::
:::
:::
::::
:::: {.column width="2%"}
::::
:::: {.column width="58%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}

Recall the layers from Part 1:

```{r globals-aes-sol, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, fig.align='center', out.height='100%', out.width='100%'}
knitr::include_graphics("../img/global-aes.png")
```

If we map aesthetics in `ggplot()`, all the following `geom_*()` layers will inherit these aesthetics

:::
:::
::::
:::::

## Local mapping 

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
Mapping aesthetics globally and then adding the `geom_*()` function results in the same graph as when we map aesthetics locally (inside the `geom_*()` function)
:::



::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
```{r local-map-ex, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|2|3|4"
ggplot(data = penguins,
  mapping = aes(
    x = bill_length_mm,
    y = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_point() +
    labs_bill_vs_flippper
```
:::
:::
:::
::::
:::: {.column width="2%"}
::::
:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
```{r local-map-sol, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "3-4"
ggplot(data = penguins) +
  geom_point(mapping = 
      aes(x = bill_length_mm,
          y = flipper_length_mm)) +
  labs_bill_vs_flippper
```
:::
:::
::::
:::::

## The `ggplot2` templates (refresher)

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
The template from part 1 uses local mappings (i.e. aesthetic mappings are set inside the `geom_*` function).
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r ggp2-temp, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
# Recall our template from Part 1
ggplot(data = <DATA>) +
  geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>))
```
:::

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
Below we've adjusted the template to include global mappings (and the option to include aesthetic mappings locally)
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r adj-ggp2-temp, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
# Adjusted template
ggplot(data = <DATA>,
  mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) + # global mappings
  geom_*(mapping = aes(<AESTHETIC MAPPINGS>)) # local mappings
```
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.65em;"}
Read more [here.](https://ggplot2-book.org/collective-geoms.html#different-groups-on-different-layers)
:::

Local

::: {.incremental}

## `graph 10`: Histograms (special bar-graphs)

<br>

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
The `geom_histogram()` function uses 'bins' to represent counts for each value
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}

::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Create new labels
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.40em;"}
```{r g10-ex-1, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
labs_bodymass_vs_species <- ggplot2::labs(
  title = "Body mass by species of Palmer penguins",
  subtitle = "Counts for adult foraging penguins",
  x = "Body Mass (grams)",
  fill = "Species")
```
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Create a histogram of `body_mass_g`, colored (filled) by
`species`
```{r g10-ex-2, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|4|5"
ggplot(data = penguins) +
  geom_histogram(
    mapping = aes(
      x = body_mass_g,
      fill = species)) +
    labs_bodymass_vs_species
```
:::

:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}
::::

:::: {.column width="58%"}
::: {.fragment}

# Mapping vs. setting aesthetics

## Mapping vs. setting (1 of 2)

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.70em;"}
Variables are mapped to aesthetics *inside* `aes()`
:::
::: {style="font-size: 0.50em;"}
```{r map-vs-set-1, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE, fig.align='left'}
#| code-line-numbers: "|6"
ggplot(data = penguins_no_miss) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = 
      aes(x = bill_length_mm,
          y = flipper_length_mm,
          color = sex)) + # inside
      labs_bill_vs_flippper
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}

::::

:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size: 0.70em;"}
Values are set outside the `aes()` function 
:::
::: {style="font-size: 0.50em;"}
```{r map-vs-set-2, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE, fig.align='right'}
#| code-line-numbers: "|6"
ggplot(data = penguins_no_miss) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = 
      aes(x = bill_length_mm,
          y = flipper_length_mm),
          color = "dodgerblue") + # outside
      labs_bill_vs_flippper
```
:::
:::
::::
:::::

## Mapping vs. setting (2 of 2)

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.05em;"}
From [ggplot2 book](https://ggplot2-book.org/layers.html#setting-mapping)
:::

. . .

<br><br>

> "*If you want appearance to be governed by a variable, put the specification inside `aes()`; if you want override the default size or colour, put the value outside of `aes()`.*"


## `graph 12`: Setting graph aesthetics

# Combining layers

## `graph 13`: New layer, new data, no problem

. . .

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.80em;"}
Each `geom_*()` function also has a `data` argument, so we can supply new data at each layer
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Create a dataset of the max bill length and depth, body mass and flipper length (`big_penguins`):
:::
::: {style="font-size: 0.50em;"}
```{r big_penguins, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
big_penguins <- bind_rows(
  slice_max(penguins, bill_length_mm, n = 1),
  slice_max(penguins, bill_depth_mm, n = 1),
  slice_max(penguins, flipper_length_mm, n = 1),
  slice_max(penguins, body_mass_g, n = 1)
)
```
:::
:::
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="2%"}
::::

:::: {.column width="49%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Create data `label` and `source`
:::
::: {style="font-size: 0.37em;"}
```{r label-source, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
big_penguins <- mutate(big_penguins,
 label = case_when(
  bill_length_mm == 59.6 ~ paste0("long bill = ", bill_length_mm),
  bill_depth_mm == 21.5 ~ paste0("deep bill = ", bill_depth_mm),
  flipper_length_mm == 231 ~ paste0("big flipper = ", flipper_length_mm),
  body_mass_g == 6300 ~ paste0("big bird = ", body_mass_g)),
 source = case_when(
  bill_length_mm == 59.6 ~ "max bill length",
  bill_depth_mm == 21.5 ~ "max bill depth",
  flipper_length_mm == 231 ~ "max flipper length",
  body_mass_g == 6300 ~ "max body mass"))
```
:::
:::
::::
:::::

## Our label dataset

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
**Objective:** Create a scatter-plot to show the relationship between body
mass, flipper length, and bill length.
:::

. . .

```{r gt-big_penguins, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE}
gt::gt(
  select(big_penguins, label, source))
```

# Facets

## Small multiples 

<br>

. . .

From [ggplot2 book](https://ggplot2-book.org/facet.html)

<br>

. . .

> "*Small multiples are a powerful tool for exploratory data analysis: you can rapidly compare patterns in different parts of the data and see whether they are the same or different.*"

## Facets = small multiples

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
In the previous graph, we used multiple aesthetics (color, size, shape)
:::

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
*Can we explore these relationships by sex or species?*
:::

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Store graph 15 in `ggp_penguin_measures`
:::
::: {style="font-size: 0.45em;"}
```{r g16-ex-1, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
ggp15_l1 <- ggplot(data = penguins_no_miss) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm,
      y = flipper_length_mm,
      size = body_mass_g),
    alpha = 1 / 3) 
```
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.55em;"}
<br> 
```{r g16-ex-2, eval=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
ggp_penguin_measures <- ggp15_l1 +
  geom_point(data = big_penguins,
    mapping = aes(
      x = bill_depth_mm,
      y = flipper_length_mm,
      color = source,
      size = body_mass_g), 
    show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_size(range = c(1, 5))
```
:::
:::
:::

::::
:::: {.column width="58%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size: 0.70em;"}

```{r g16-sol, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE}
ggp_penguin_measures
```

## `graph 16`: Facet by sex

<br>

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
Use `facet_wrap()` to view our previous graph by `sex`
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}
::: {style="font-size: 0.54em;"}

`facet_wrap()` uses `. ~ [var]`

```{r g16-ex-3, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|9"
ggp_penguin_measures +
  ggrepel::geom_label_repel(
    data = big_penguins,
    mapping = aes(
      x = bill_depth_mm,
      y = flipper_length_mm,
      label = label),
    size = 2) + # adjust size
  facet_wrap(. ~ sex) + # facet by sex
  # labels
  labs_bodymass_bill_depth_flipper_length
```
:::

## `graph 17`: Facet by species

<br>

. . .

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
Change `facet_wrap()` to build graphs by `species` and add theme
:::

<br>

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.incremental}

::: {style="font-size: 0.60em;"}
Change `facet_wrap()` to `~ species`  
Add `theme_minimal()`  and labels  
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.50em;"}
```{r g17-ex-1, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|9|11|13"
ggp_penguin_measures +
  ggrepel::geom_label_repel(
    data = big_penguins,
    mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm,
      y = flipper_length_mm,
      label = label),
    size = 2) +
  # change to species
  facet_wrap(. ~ species) +
  # add theme
  theme_minimal() +
  # labels
  labs_bodymass_bill_depth_flipper_length
```
